SnowRunner takes its time, and sometimes it feels downright exhausting - but that’s the beauty of it.
Fans of big rigs and heavy machinery will appreciate the feeling, and the game’s rhythm can even become meditative.
There’s a strange calm in navigating through rough terrain, inch by inch, until you finally break through. 
Multiplayer adds a dose of chaotic fun-digging yourselves into trouble, then engineering your own rescue.
Somehow it’s the off-road cousin of Euro Truck Simulator.

A rather unique game in its own kind. The concept is essentially simple: deliver some cargo from point A to point B, but so much can happen along the way. The game isn't perfect, of course, and the weight of some vehicles feels quite odd, as does the damage to the wheels and suspension on a seemingly perfect paved road. Playing solo is quite fun, especially if you listen to music or a podcast. However, the game becomes even better in co-op, as there are many lengthy missions that can take several hours to complete and a little help is always good. Overall, the game is definitely worth the asking price.

Overall, I really enjoy this game.  Is it repetitive, absolutely, but I don't mind.
1.	Drive here, oh, can’t reach that location.
2.	Bring materials to clear obstruction, or build bridge.
3.	Continue drive to reach location.

That is the basics, and call me unimaginative, but I like it.  The graphics are not so intense my less than top of the line computer does just fine.  I have played this game for almost 900 hours as of this review, and I can list on one hand the times it has crashed, in my book that is enough for me to buy a game these days.  In the last six months I picked up a Steam Deck, and it works phenomenally there as well.  Bit of a battery hog, but what isn’t except 8-bit games.  I have also not completed this game in all the time I have played.  I keep getting distracted by some random place I see on the map and want to drive to it.  

Can this game be difficult, absolutely.  I flipped over two large off-road trucks during a delivery to a map that does not have a garage (base of operations) and had to spend almost 30 minutes just to get another truck out there to flip them back over, only to roll that truck.  I was unhappy to say the least but still had a blast. The other thing is that leveling up to get better tires is a must, but I spent so much time doing side quests that it was a non issue.

The only drawback to this game is the lack of a solid story.  There is a bit of a bit of one and it is centered around rebuilding things in the different maps, and I have completed only one of the three main objectives.  But to be honest it does not detract from the game.

If you enjoy off-road driving in video games and a little mindless fun, then this game is a good match.

Let me preface this review by saying that this game is not for everyone.

It's slow, it's tedious, it's far too long, and it's ridiculously frustrating when you're forced to watch the massive load of cargo you painstakingly yanked across the map go tumbling into a lake because you tried to take a shortcut with a 5° grade.

But oh if it isn't incredibly satisfying when you manage to pull of an insane maneuver with equipment that in no way should be able to squeeze down that narrow dirt path. If you enjoy trucking simulators and have the patience of a rock like I do, then pick up the base game and Seasons one through 5 for hundreds upon hundreds of hours of offroading madness.

Yes, I 100%'d all seasons through Washington because I'm actually insane.

FINAL SCORE: 7/10
IN A NUTSHELL: An offroading career

In my opinion, this is a fantastic game. It’s better with friends, but still amazingly fun to play solo.

It expands on the premise of Spintires and MudRunner by adding a huge amount of content — maps, missions, cargo types, trucks, customization, and much more. And if you ever start to get bored, the Steam Workshop is enabled, so you can mod to your heart’s content.

What I don’t like, however, is that the physics feel inferior, at least in my opinion. Compared to MudRunner, the sensation of driving your truck over mud and rough terrain isn’t as satisfying. The frame of the truck feels too rigid — in MudRunner and Spintires you could see the metal twisting and fighting with the terrain, really showing how the trucks struggled while carrying heavy cargo. That made progress feel more rewarding. Here, the physics sometimes cause vehicles to fly or get flung around, which breaks immersion.

All that said, it’s still a faithful continuation of the series, and the huge amount of extra content is a big plus.

You do not bounce in soft mud in reality, you sink! Have the clowns who made this game ever been off-roading in their life, or did they just program this game thinking this is what off-roading is.  The physics have no bearing in physical reality ?  But this game seems to think you can bounce all over the place in quick sand? Update: I manage to find an original copy of the first game in the series made by this developer, SPIN TIRES, now that is an off-road simulator.  The trucks actually have a valid gearbox, the physics are like real life off-roading, your truck has weight to it, you can build momentum and speed as well, it doesn’t feel like you may launch into orbit with Sputnik like Snowrunner, you don’t bounce around like you are on a bumpy sheet of glass.  The chassis of the truck flex and bend, small trees break under load and larger ones bend from your truck up to a certain size.  The environments don’t give you serious damage or damage out of nowhere unless you really hit something hard.  I enjoyed SpinTires so much I played it for like 7 hours today.  I then bought Mudrunner which is the second game by this developer.  It is like a graphically updated SpinTires, it basically looks like Snowrunner, but with different locations, and was the predecessor of Snowrunner.  That is the game I recommend you play if you have an itch for an off-road simulator.  You likely won’t be able to find a copy of SpinTires unless you are internet “SAVVY”. I do not recommend the sorry excuse for a physics engine that Snow Runner has.  Essentially, the only thing Snowrunner has on Mudrunner and SpinTires is wider variety of missions and more dlc, and what looks to be slightly better graphics, which is meaningless in 2025.  Literally everything else about the game is worse. And dumbed down.  Why, to be released on console.  SpinTires is a legit pc off-road simulator.  Which Mudrunner was dumbed down from SpinTires and Snow Runner is a game for those who still crap themselves and have not been potty trained yet. 

Apparently, the Publisher and Developer had a dispute while making DLC for SpinTires and parted ways. Sued each other, and the dev made Mudrunner.  However SpinTires still existed.  Obviously whatever happened in their dispute the publisher had to take down SpinTires.  However, the engine utilized in Snowrunner had to be different from MudRunenr and SpinTires.  Why…who the hell knows.  Maybe it was a settled agreement.  But all I can tell you is when the dev coded this game, they did it like a rabid mongoose on Crystal Meth.  Nothing about the physics engine or game mechanics make sense, and there are colossal bugs in the game that make it down right unplayable or infuriating, self abusing even.

So I recommend if you have a desire to play an actual off-road simulator, play Mudrunner or try a find SpinTires as it is the superior one and I played the hell out of it today.  It is exactly what I was hoping this game was, but it isn’t.  Sadly. I cannot recommend Snowrunner, as it is a broken game, which is really disappointing, because I am now a fan of the first two installments.  So it has nothing to do with difficulty or skill, as SpinTires is more difficult as a game.  Snowrunners bugs make it unplayable and difficult from ineptitude of the dev’s physic engine design choices.  All they had to do was reuse the same engine, or code the same values.  I mean damn, he shit the bed.  Also, Roadcraft has the same engine as Snowrunner, so this STD plague of a physics engine is now cascading into this devs other titles, with a semi truck game on the way too, yikes . Unless you got SR for like 4 dollars, then maybe it is worth it. Save your money. Save your sanity.  As this game starts off slow before you start realizing the bugs and glaring errors, unless you play challenge mode initially. Where I found all the bugs. Which are game breaking and make it unplayable, infuriating.  I am trying to protect you as a consumer.  Not to waste your money on a broken game that will screw you over later on in gameplay, secretly hiding its inadequate, buggy and unrealistic engine.

So my review stands.  Unless you want to mod the piss out of it I wouldn’t play it.

This all brings me back to the money dispute between Pavel who works for Saber and the Oovee Game Studios Publisher. It's also never explained how a gas station has the ability to talk or feel a sense of ownership over a trailer, but okay, whatever. I'll get your trailer.

Snowrunner gives me access to about 15 functionally-identical trucks, and presumably ONE of them is capable of traversing the swamp to retrieve the trailer. I have no idea which one it is, and the game is obviously not going to tell me, because then I might accidentally bypass the core gameplay loop, which is getting stuck in the mud & giving up after 45 minutes.

Anyhow, to its credit, Snowrunner very accurately simulates the profound frustration of dealing with an uncooperative, immobile motor vehicle; I'd much rather be doing anything else, just like in real life! But otherwise, it's a post-apocalyptic madhouse of talking buildings, self-assembling bridges, teleportation, and tutorial pop-ups that insist I should be using the winch, while I'm actively using the winch.

A sentient, talking gas station gives me a task: retrieve its fuel trailer from the eastern swamp. It is never explained how the trailer got there, given that there are no other moving vehicles in the game, let alone any other humans or living beings. It's also never explained how a gas station has the ability to talk or feel a sense of ownership over a trailer, but okay, whatever. I'll get your trailer.

Snowrunner gives me access to about 15 functionally-identical trucks, and presumably ONE of them is capable of traversing the swamp to retrieve the trailer. I have no idea which one it is, and the game is obviously not going to tell me, because then I might accidentally bypass the core gameplay loop, which is getting stuck in the mud & giving up after 45 minutes.

Anyhow, to its credit, Snowrunner very accurately simulates the profound frustration of dealing with an uncooperative, immobile motor vehicle; I'd much rather be doing anything else, just like in real life! But otherwise, it's a post-apocalyptic madhouse of talking buildings, self-assembling bridges, teleportation, and tutorial pop-ups that insist I should be using the winch, while I'm actively using the winch.
